content.description:
This is a new route put up on the left side of Black and Tan. I thought I was getting on the 10a (Crime and Punishment) but this route goes at a more difficult grade.

This route is fairly new, owing to all the fresh drill dust and is not in the guidebooks. Start up the easy grey slab and things get quite vertical once the rock goes orange. Finish on to the large ledge with a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This route is in between the 11b Idiosyncratic Feedback Mechanism (on the left) and Crime and Punishment (on the right).

content.description: On the far left side of Black and Tan is a small alcove known as the Annex that contains three routes, about thirty feet right of the Annex are a couple of short slabby routes of which this is the right of the two.  This route starts up the easy low angle slab past a few bolts, then pulls a little bit of a steeper (but very well protected) bulge just before the anchors.  The crux is the bulge, but there are great holds, so it stays very easy.  Well bolted and a great route for someone's first lead.
content.protection: Bolts (maybe 5) to two bolt anchor connected with a chain.  Single quicklink for lowering off.
content.location: Between the Annex and the main Black and Tan wall are two slabby routes, this is the right of the two and is very short with the obvious chain anchor.

content.description: A fun addition to the cliff.   Climb up the shallow dihedral to its end and then figure out the sequence to reach a stance.   Pretty cruiser to the finish.
content.location: On the right side of the cliff.    Pass Jumanji and go under the large boulder leaning on the cliff.   First route you come to after walking under boulder.

content.description: Fun movement between decent crimps and some jugs. The rock is even more sharp on this side.
content.location: Second level, far right around the corner. If you're looking at the corner this is the first route to the right. The next one to the right would be Pangs.

content.description:
While this route is really only a 10' boulder problem, it’s a really fun boulder problem.  This boulder problem would be a classic V7/8 anywhere in the country.

Start up in the back of the cave on harder than it looks climbing to a jug, relax and jug bash into the roof for a few clips,  Compose yourself and launch into the crux when the jugs run out.  Lot's of foot trickery will be key here.  Snatch the finally decent crimp, clip and shake out on the huge undercling sidepull.  Two more clips of insecure tech fest (but much easier) take you to the anchor.
content.protection: Bolts to anchors, currently has fixed draws
content.location: Start in the deepest recess of the upper cave.  To the left is a project, then "Smoking Drum", to the right is "Breaking the Law"

content.description: Grab a jug rail at the start of the roof and either campus out to a second jug rail or use some foot trickery then gain a right hand incut flake and do the crux which involves some crazy tension, toe hooking, and bad bad feet.  From here comes a decent rest on a jug complex with ok feet...rest up because the next 20 feet involves sustained bouldery climbing with big moves to decent holds, although not as hard as the start crux.  Finish up in a harder than it looks dihedral on weird facing holds and an off balance clip. Fight to the top and clip the chains.  Now you can rest.
content.protection:
Bolts with fixed draws to the top.  Stick clip the first fixed draw and put a draw on the lowest bolt for your belayer and a single biner on the 2nd bolt to keep the rope out of the way for the start.

Anchors at the top with biners.
content.location: 2nd tier of the black and tan on the far left steepest side.  Starts on obvious chalked under cling jug.

content.description: Probably not even worth posting, but from the ground I had assumed that the two routes on the slab between The Annex and the main Black and Tan wall shared the obvious chain anchor about 30 feet off the ground.  I went up the left route (Slabstick) and headed to the anchor of the right route.  This avoids the crux of the left route and pulls the crux of the right route, so the rating stays the same as either route.  Though easy, there is a slight runout (compared to the rest of the bolting on the two routes) getting from the left to the right, so not quite as good of a first lead as either route individually would be.  Climb to the third bolt of the left route, then head right on great holds to the bulge on the right route.
content.protection: Bolts (5, I think) to 2 bolt anchor connected by a chain with a quicklink for lowering off of.
content.location: linkup of the two slab routes between the Annex and the main Black and Tan wall.

content.description: On the far left side of Black and Tan is a small alcove known as the Annex that contains three routes, about thirty feet right of the Annex are a couple of short slabby routes of which this is the left of the two.  This route starts up the easy low angle slab past a few bolts, then finishes up a flake at the top of the wall for a couple of bolts.  The crux is probably right in the middle of the route where it gets a tiny bit steeper but you don't yet have the flake to use.  Well bolted and a great route for someone's first lead.
content.protection: bolts (7 I think) to 2 bolt anchor
content.location: Between the Annex and the main Black and Tan wall are two slabby routes, this is the left of the two and is longer than the one to the right of it.

content.description: Just to the left of shades of grey is a line of new bolts painted black.
content.location: to the right of the fence, to the left of shades of grey.

content.description: A shorter route on a bulging wall. Great movement and features from crimps to pockets to slopers. Get on it.
content.location: Second route right of the green fence; right of route with black hangars.

content.description: Long slab that gets steeper as you go. Really good movement on sweet features and bomber rock.
content.protection: 10 bolts and anchors. Mid station rap anchors will help you off with a sixty otherwise equip yourself with a seventy meter.
content.location: This route and Beauty Pageant start on a grey ramp to the right of the scooping section that Da Riddler and Dickheads is on.

content.description: Easy slab route that keeps your attention due to the disastrous consequences of a fall-think motorcycle road rash, then add cayenne pepper. VERY grippy rock, fun moves, most of the holds on this were *heavily* "comfortized", but I wouldn't go so far as to call it chipped. A decent route and a nice option when the moderates at Kelly's Rock are in the sun.
content.protection: Can't get off this one with a 50 meter-bring a 60 meter rope or longer to lower-my ends weren't touching the ground with a 60.
content.location: Starts at the very left end of the leftmost cave at Black and Tan. Climbs out of an alcove up a slab.

content.description:
This route has everything.

stick clip recommended. Then well bolted.  Hard start,fun O.W. hand jams,big pockets and mussy hooks. Radical! Dont forget to chicken wing!
content.location: Right side of crag. Near tickman.

content.description: The route starts out on textured sharp brown rock through the first bolt.   Getting to the 2nd bolt is the crux.   From here its nice positive holds and then an easy run to the anchors.
content.location: On the far right side of the cliff.  Pass under the leaning block and go around the corner.  This is to the right of Tickman, 11b.

content.description: Shared start with Sniffing glue then traverse left on crimps and side pulls. After looking at several printed and online sources, half call this 14a and half call it 14b. Most well rounded climbers seem to think it’s a notch easier than breakin the law.
content.location: Shared start with sniffing glue. Look for the pile of rocks at the base.

content.description: Start on 2 decent holds and find a sequence to reach up and establish on a right facing flake (crux).  From here, the climbing eases up substantially to the finish.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 5 if linking into Beauty Pageant or Resolve.  Anchors above Dull Boy, 5.11d and Bed Head, 5.11c.
content.location: This routes begins about 20 feet to the left of the shared start for Beauty Pageant, 5.10a and Resolve, 5.10b.  It's the right most line of bolts on the first tier.

content.description: The crux is a powerful boulder problem right off the ground.  Followed by great edges and a couple long moves.  There are only three bolts, but they are well placed and it never feels unsafe.
content.location: First route 10' left of the fence.

content.description: This pitch starts about half way up the easy slab of Resolve (5.10b). After about 45ft, pull right onto the narrow panel of rock for Magic Carpet Ride.  Subtle and deceiveing moves leads you to a two bolt anchor after about 105ft.  A 70M will get you down, but I didn't test a 60M.
content.protection:
12 bolts if starting on

Beauty Pageant/Resolve

; 8 bolts if starting from the ramp above.

Rap anchors.
content.location: The right hand arete about 50ft up Resolve...

content.description:
This route starts off with some thin moves on the slab. After the first bolt of

Redolence

move to the right and follow the line of bolts that continue up and to the right. Holds are thin and require some thought up until the 4th bolt or so, after which the climb changes personality. More features are available in the little runnels that have formed. The difficulty eases, and the bolts get farther and farther apart up to the ring anchors.

When lowering off this route you will end up 30 feet or more to the right of your belayer. Have a second clean the climb. Don't try to clean this while lowering, or on rappel. You will get some nasty scratches on the sharp rock when you swing.
content.protection: 8 or 9 bolts to rings (assuming I recall correctly).
content.location:
On the left side of the caves at Black and Tan. Shares the first bolt of

Redolence

then skirts off to the right.

content.description: Sweet pockets to some face crimping.
content.location: The route to the right of Shades of Grey

content.description:
This route starts to the left of

Crime and Punishment

, following a couple of bolts through the same initial slab.

The slab start is maybe around 5.9 and very sharp and precise. At the third bolt you'll be mostly standing up straight and by the 4th you'll be slightly hanging from your arms. Clip the 5th bolt and rest at the massive jugs between the 4th and 5th bolt. The crux is well protected by that 5th bolt and the 6th bolt has a great clipping hold. The climbing eases up to the anchor.
content.location:
Starts on the same slab as and climbs to the left of

Crime and Punishment

.

content.description: Start on a slab ramp to reach some friable vertical rock that leads to a break under the orange overhanging wall.  The crux is between the 3rd and 4th bolt.  From here, its nice climbing on very sharp pockets and in cut holds.  The rock quality improves by the 2nd bolt.  A good warm up in the sun for some of the harder routes around the corner.
content.location: This is the leftmost route at this cliff(excluding    "the annex" down by the wash).

content.description:
The only trad line at the crag... If the approach was longer I would have bolted it.

Climb hand crack then trend left to finger lieback. Crux is protected by a bolt(originally done with out)

A army ring piton protect the start.

Bring your hand jammies crack is sharp!
content.location: Walk past fence and round the leaning boulder to a open book dihedral. Look for a army ring piton for the start.

content.description: A long, low-angled, fun climb on sharp limestone. Lots of positive holds, including the edges of a couple of flakes. The rock is rough enough and the climb low-angled enough you could probably smear all the way up if you wanted to.
content.protection: 8 bolts to Metolius rap anchors (with a quicklink on the left anchor). The rock is rough, there are some sharp edges, and the climb is low-angled so we belayed from the top and then the belayer rappelled rather than lowered to save wear and tear (and worry).
content.location:
At the left side of this crag is a big, obvious roof (the left of the two big roofs) with a gentle ramp rising right-to-left under it. At the end of the ramp is an obvious small rock tower below a rounded ridge which forms the left edge of the main face of the

Black and Tan

crag.

Just right of that small tower is a sheltered, flat platform above which is a notch with a bolt in it, leading to more bolts above. This is the start of the route

Redolence.

Glutton for Punishment

is on the

left

side of the small rock tower. It's easy to get around the tower by dropping down from the platform and following ledges around to its left side, then up to a wide gentle area below a moderate slab rising to the left of the rounded ridge.

Glutton

starts from bottom center of slab with two tan-painted bolts above, leading to a gentle diagonal right-to-left ramp about 25-30 feet up.

The rounded ridge has two obvious left-facing inside corners (

Redolence

goes up roughly in between those two corners). After its second bolt,

Glutton

crosses right across the ramp (while another bolt line continues more left), then goes up roughly along the left one of those two corners (which forms the boundary between the upper slab and the ridge -- then finishes right to a 2-bolt anchor with rap rings (shared with

Redolence

) at the top of the ridge.

content.description: Pull through the initial overhang and trend leftwards through the shallow corner before heading up the easier face to a shared anchor with Da Riddler.
content.location: Immediately right of Da Riddler

content.description: A left-trending start on good, albeit sharp rock leads to an easier finish.
content.location: Past the fence to the right at the upper wall.  Two routes past Shades of Gray.

content.description:
Start on a slabby face around the corner (see beta photo) and make the first couple of tricky moves to the first bolt. Continue on easier terrain up a narrow rib (some exciting exposure) to a steeper face with good holds. Finish on a nice ledge.

The Todd Goss guidebook lists it as 5.8. I found the first move probably 5.7, the rest of climb was not much harder. The easy middle section on exposed and narrow rib is exciting and adds a nice character to the route.
content.protection: Six bolts to two bolt anchor. The first bolt may be pre-clipped by stepping up some blocky terrain on the right side of the start. This is recommended as the first moves is the crux of route.
content.location: On the right side of Black & Tan, see beta photo.

content.description: This is a bouldery route, and a great intro to the area. A boulder problem starts off the route, leading to some sequential pocket climbing, a rather thin crux, and then easier climbing to the anchor. The crux comes just before the third bolt, where an undercling can be helpful. This route is most definitely a Black and Tan classic.
content.location: This is the fourth route from the right of the lower wall. There is a draw hanging on the second bolt, and the route begins on a chalky undercling.

content.description: Climb Crime and Punishment and after 5 bolts cut right. Criminal Mischief continues for 5 more bolts to an anchor at the top of the cliff.
content.location: Shares the first 5 bolts of Crime and Punishment and then cuts right.

content.description: Fun route that has good variety of angles from slabbing to slightly overhanging to bulging. Awesome holds.
content.location:
Start the same as

Glutton for Punishment:

around the bottom center of the wide slab to the left of the obvious small rock tower with a rounded ridge above it.

After the second bolt you'll reach a gentle ramp. Where

Glutton

goes right to the left-facing, inside corner which forms the boundary between the upper slab and the rounded ridge, instead go left.

After three more bolts the route

Criminal Mischief

trends right up the slab to its own anchor above.

Crime and Punishment

bears left up over steep bulge, then more gently up and left to the anchor.

content.description:
This quintessential Power Endurance line features two back-to-back cruxes low to the ground.  The business boils down to crimping through 10-or-so consecutive moves, some of which are quite powerful.  The rock is flawless and not as sharp as one might expect.  This line was originally conceived and prepped by the visionaries Tim Wagner and Jeff Pedersen.  In 2001, the FA was nabbed without regard to Pedersen's redtag.

A few long but easy reaches leads to a traverse under the roof.  The first crux is a burly lunge to reach good edges at the lip of the roof.  Apparently taller climbers can get a big stem/dropknee here, taking the sting out of the first crux (hence the inevitable internet-hand-wringing over the grade).  After a tenuous clip, make a desparate pull onto the headwall utilizing nasty crimps.  The headwall is mostly trivial, featuring numerous great rests, and relatively big holds, but there is one dicey slab move that will certainly get your attention.
content.protection: About 10 bolts to Springer Cold Shuts.  Those dynoing to the lip of the roof will probably want a single biner on the fourth bolt to prevent forking the quickdraw.
content.location: On the left end of the upper Black & Tan cave, there is a steep dihedral heading out the roof.  Breakin the Law climbes directly to the point where this dihedral meets the lip of the roof.  It is also the third bolted line from the left that climbs out the roof of the cave.

content.description:
It completely amazes me that the legendary Boone Speed took the time to establish this forgetable line.  My theory is that he needed something warm for a belay slave to climb while he worked some burly project in the adjacent caves.  This route, and the two lines to it's left (that make up "The Annex") have but one thing going for them: they remain in the sun for a few hours after the rest of crag is in the shade.

Begin above jumbled boulders, and do the crux to gain the route.  If you're able to pull off the ground, the rest of the route will be trivial.  Wander past bushes and choss for a while to reach a poor anchor.
content.protection: Around 5 bolts to a poor 2-bolt anchor.  Bring some quicklinks if you do this to fix the anchor.
content.location: On the far left end of the Black and Tan massif (only a few feet above the wash that runs between the cliff and the road) is a small alcove of mungy rock.  This is the right-most, and longest, of three routes in this alcove.

content.description: You might want to stick clip the second bolt to prevent possible ground fall.   Bouldery start.   Traverse right past 2nd bolt and aim for 3rd bolt out right.   (if you continue straight up its Dull Boy, 5.11d).   Climbing eases up significantly after 3rd bolt.
content.location: 2nd bolted line from the right side of the lower overhang terrace.

content.description: The routes starts off on the same ramp as Resolve then moves left at the mid station rap anchors, it then climbs above Da Riddler and up some technical vertical climbing to the chains.
content.location: this route shares the first four bolts with Resolve then moves left and up through another 5 or 6 bolts to anchors.

content.description:
Pitch 1: Clip the first two bolts on Learning Curve then traverse right clipping bolts as you go. You will pass over the anchor for the 5.13 route Disrepect. Continue moving right until you obtain the anchor on a ledge above the roof, at the base of a dirty corner.

Pitch 2: Climb the corner. Toward the top you will move a little toward the right.

One rappel with a single 60m rope from the top of the climb will get you down to the floor of the cave.
content.location: This route shares the start with Learning Curve, in a notch to the left of the wide cave.
